Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story:
My phone buzzes on the edge of my desk, the familiar ringtone of my parents’ number echoing through the quiet office. It’s Sunday evening—our weekly call. I glance at the clock: 7:03 p.m. I should have wrapped up by now, but the code on my screen blinks with errors, and the team’s messages pile up in the group chat. The project manager’s last note is clear: “We can’t move forward until your module is done.” I know everyone is waiting on me, and the deadline is tomorrow morning.

But my parents expect this call. Every week, I hear the relief in their voices when I ask about their health, their garden, the neighbors. They worry if I miss it, and I promised I wouldn’t let work get in the way. My fingers hover over the mouse, torn between opening the video call app and diving back into the code. My heart pounds with guilt and frustration, caught between being the reliable daughter my parents need and the dependable engineer my team expects. The phone keeps ringing, and I can’t decide which world to answer first.
